loans.name: Mbuzi Twekambe Group

texts.en:
Dimitiria is a 35 year old married woman with three children living in a semi permanent house in Fort Portal Uganda. Ever since her husband resorted to daily alcohol drinking, she has been solely taking care of the family and her dream is to educate her children up to university.

She is a farmer as well as a vendor of fresh foods and has been doing so for five years, amidst challenges of price fluctuations. Her dream is to have a food store. Dimitiria needs the loan to buy maize and cassava flour for resale. Of the nine members in the group, only eight took the loan. It is a group policy that each member guarantees the other in acquiring credit facilities, so the ninth member is included as well.

loans.use: to buy  maize and cassava flour for resale.

loans.name: Nurhayati's Group

texts.en:
NurhayA. is 26 years old. In 2010 she started to sell "Gamis" clothes on credit. "Gamis" are Moslem clothes. From this business she can help her family's financial situation.

 Now, she will use a part of her loan to add more "Gamis" clothes with more variation. She believes that in this fasting month, her sales will increase. In the future she wants to expand her business by having her own kiosk, because now she only sells from her house.

loans.use: to buy "Gamis" clothes.

loans.name: Marcial De Jesus

texts.es: Marcial  de 59 años tiene un taller donde confecciona prendas de vestir, él vive en la ciudad de Barranquilla y tiene un hijo de 12 años de edad. Inicialmente el taller lo emprendió su esposa, pero no continuaron trabajando juntos y él buscó un lugar donde independizarse y desde hace dos años se encuentra en ese sitio, donde le ha ido bien y tiene muchas aspiraciones de continuar creciendo y de lograr mas adelante tener su propio local. Su mayor desafío es el capital de trabajo, que le resulta insuficiente para el cumplimiento de sus metas; en la actualidad está aplicando a su credikiva,   primer financiamiento que recibe de la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo con el cual comprará materias primas e insumos, como telas, hilos, correderas para poder satisfacer la demanda e incrementar sus ventas en un 15%. En su negocio maneja unos buenos índices de liquidez, lo que le dan la oportunidad de cancelar obligaciones a corto plazo, sus cuentas por cobrar rotan rápidamente y sus niveles de rentabilidad le generan solvencia, indicadores financieros desde los cuales proyectamos su potencial crecimiento y auguramos que su inversión sea exitosa.
texts.en:
Marcial, 59, has a workshop where he makes articles of clothing.  He lives in the city of Barranquilla and has a 12-year-old son.  His wife initially started the workshop but they did not continue to work together and he found a place to become independent and has been there for the last two years.  He’s done very well and he has many desires to continue growing and to later own a place of his own.  

His greatest challenge is working capital which is insufficient for him to reach his goals.  He is currently applying for his Kiva loan, the first financing he receives from Fundación Mario Santo Domingo that he’ll use to buy raw materials and supplies like fabric, thread and zippers to meet demand and increase sales by 15%.

He manages good liquidity indexes in his business which allows him to repay his debts in short amounts of time.  His accounts receivable turn over rapidly and his profit levels generate solvency, financial indicators from which we can project potential growth and we augur that his investment will be successful.

loans.use: to buy raw materials and supplies like fabric, thread and zippers.

loans.name: Dionisio

texts.en:
Dinisio is a hardworking man. He is 38 years old and married. Dionisio has had a hog raising business for ten years. Aside from hog raising, he also farms. 

Dinisio raises pigs for additional income to support his family's daily needs. He is requesting a loan of 10,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) to buy feed and vitamins to maintain the quality of his pigs for sale in the future.

loans.use: to buy feed and vitamins for his pigs.

loans.name: Jay-Ar

texts.en:
Jay-Ar is 25 years old and is single. He runs a hog-raising business, primarily hogs for breeding. He dreams that his business will grow so he can extend his financial support to his parents before he builds his own family. He continues working hard to be able to attain his goal.

Jay-Ar has 3 sows and 14 piglets. He has been experiencing difficulties sustaining his pigs because feed is costly now.  He therefore decided to request a loan of 25,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) to buy feed for his pigs. He hopes to maintain his business until he gets married and builds his own family.

loans.use: to buy feed for his pigs.

loans.name: Khursheed Begum's Group

texts.en:
Khursheed Begum is married with four children. Her elder son reads in 5th standard, while her younger son is in 4th standard. Her elder daughter is in 3rd standard and her youngest one is in class one. 

Khurhseed is a caring lady by nature. She gets up early in the morning, readies her kids for school and prepares breakfast for her family, then cleans the whole house. After finishing the household work, she does sewing work to fulfill orders on time. She manages both jobs very efficiently.  

She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah to buy another sewing machine for expanding her business further. She will hire an assistant as well, which will help her with getting good orders and earning a better income. 

She is confident that through the loan investment, she will take her business to a more profitable position.

loans.use: To buy another sewing machine for a sewing business.

loans.name: Hermes Felipe

texts.es:
Don Hermes esta en mejores condiciones ya que sus anquilinos han aumentado, siendo su negocio el alquiler de cuartos y un taxi.  pues su casa la construyo de dos pisos, el cual ha ido terminando, atraves de los financiamiento y dando mejoras a los cuartos. Sus hijos siguen cursando el colegio, y su esposa es ama de casa.
Con este nuevo prestamo don Hermes, mejorara el techo de unos de los cuarto que alquila, dando buen servicio habitacional, a si como repellara las habitaciones del segundo piso, pondra ceramica, siendo el de su uso personal.
 Para el es de gran sastifaccion el poder seguir mejorando su casa, para el bienestar comun de su familia. ya que con mucho esmero y esfuerzo, trabaja dia a dia, en su taxi para cumplir sus compromiso de pagos y gastos personales, estando todo ah altos costos.
texts.en:
Hermes is doing better because the number of his tenants has increased since his business is renting rooms and driving a taxi.  He is building a two story house that he’s almost finished with.  With the loans he’s been improving the rooms.  His children continue in school and his wife’s a housewife.

With this new loan, Hermes will improve the roof on one of the rental rooms providing good housing service and will also plaster the rooms on the second story and install tile flooring since these are the rooms for his personal use.

For him, it is of great satisfaction to be able to continue improving his house for his family’s wellbeing because with much dedication and effort he works daily driving his taxi to make his payments and cover personal expenses since everything is so expensive now

loans.use: to plaster the walls, install tile flooring upstairs and make improvements to a rental room.

loans.name: Jijuka Group

texts.fr:
Laurent est un commerçant âgé de 63ans qui habite la localité de Gitongo de la Province de Gitega au centre du pays. Il fait le commerce du lait depuis 6 ans. Il commence ce métier après avoir termine son emploi avec l’ONG Solidarité. Il fait ses études jusqu’en 6e année primaire. Son épouse est une cultivatrice et tous leurs enfants sont déjà maries.
 Le crédit Kiva  de 290,000 francs burundais qu’il obtient lui permet d’augmenter son capital pour acheter de grandes quantités de lait à revendre  afin de réaliser de grands bénéfices et accroitre ses économies. 

Il est membre  du groupe  communautaire« Jijuka»
texts.en:
Laurent, age 63, is a merchant who lives in Gitongo, Gitega Province, in the center of the country. He's been selling milk for six years. He started this business after finishing his job with NGO Solidarité.

He attended elementary school up to the sixth year. His wife is a cultivator, and all their children are already married.

He's seeking a loan of BIF 290'000 (ca US$ 230) from Kiva, to bolster his working capital in order to buy large quantities of milk to resell, and increase his profits and savings.

He's a member of Jijuka Group.

loans.use: to buy large quantities of milk

loans.name: Batbayar

texts.en:
Mr. Batbayar, 46, runs a motorcycle transportation business around his town. He has been running his business since last year; he is retired last year from the Military Force of Mongolia. He lives with one of his daughters and his wife. Most of his children have moved out from their parents' house and always try to support their parents with what they can do. This time they also promised to support him in repaying his loan. 

Lately his motorcycle has became damaged; some of it's parts cannot be repaired. Therefore he is taking a loan to purchase some new spare parts for his motorcycle in order to continue his business successfully.

loans.use: to  purchase the some of new spare parts for his motorcycle.

loans.name: Vincent

texts.en:
Vincent is 41 years old and lives in the Fort Portal region of Uganda. He is married and has six children; four of them are currently in school. For the past 13 years, Vincent has been working hard to manage his welding shop, which does metal work and repairs. 

To help expand his business, Vincent has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more bars for making windows, doors and gates, and will help Vincent to generate greater profits and improve his family's well-being. Vincent hopes that in the future he will be able to have many customers and contracts. 

Vincent is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small-scale entrepreneurs like Vincent who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more bars for making windows, doors and gates.

loans.name: Marta Alicia

texts.es: Marta Alicia,ella tiene 37 años de edad es una persona que se caracteriza por ser una persona luchadora por la vida,ella se dedica a la venta de productos comestibles desde hace 7 años,nos cuenta que desde que ella inicio con su negocio a estado luchando para que su negocio prospere le da gracias a Dios por aberle dado la oportunidad de tener este negocio que le a serbido de mucha ayuda,esta solicitando este credito para la compra de productos comestibles ya que siente que nececita mas capital para trabajar,el sueño de ella es tener una tienda mas grande y ayudar a su familia.
texts.en:
Marta Alicia is 37 years old and a person characterized by her fighting spirit in life. She has been selling groceries for seven years, and tells us that since she started her business she has been fighting to make her business thrive. She thanks God for having given her the chance to have this business that has been of great help to her.  

She is requesting this loan to buy groceries, because she feels that she needs more capital for her work. Her dream is to have a bigger shop and help her family.

loans.use: to buy groceries.

loans.name: Micheal

texts.en:
Micheal lives in Malindi, Kenya. He is single and has operated a motorcycle transportation business for the last seven months. 
He borrowed some money and added some of his personal savings, which enabled him purchase a motorcycle. 

Micheal heard about Milango from friends, and decided to join in order to finance his business. He is applying for a loan of KES 40,000 to help pay for another motorcycle. He will use the extra income from this loan to improve his savings and to purchase other assets.

loans.use: to purchase another motorcycle.

loans.name: Mahudjro Group

texts.fr: Le groupe MAHUDJRO est composé de trois personnes qui habitent dans le même quartier. C'est la quatrième fois que ce groupe sollicite l'aide financier de ALIDé, afin d'élever le niveau de son activité. La représentante  du groupe, du nom de Albertine est celle qui a la main levée sur la photo. Albertine est âgée de 37 ans et vit au Bénin. Albertine n’a pas fréquenté l’école. Albertine est mariée à un conducteur de taxi du nom de Janvier. Le couple a trois enfants tous scolarisés et à leur charge. Le couple assure ensemble les charges de la famille. Afin d‘assurer les diverses charges de la maison, Albertine vend depuis une dizaine d’année des plastiques et des tissus par le système de distribution. Parallèlement à cette activité, Albertine vend des chaussures. Albertine s’approvisionne dans un marché du Bénin. Dans la quête de la satisfaction de sa clientèle et pour accroître son chiffre d’affaires et son revenu, Albertine sollicite ensemble avec les autres membres du groupe MAHUDJRO, un quatrième crédit auprès de ALIDé. Les trois premiers prêts ont été bien remboursés.
texts.en:
The Mahudjro group consists of three people who live in the same neighborhood. This is the fourth time that this group is requesting financial aid from ALIDé, in order to elevate the level of their business.

The representative of the group, by the name of Albertine, is the one who has her hand raised on the photo. Albertine is 37 years old and lives in Bénin. Albertine did not go to school. Albertine is married to a taxi driver named Janvier. The couple has three dependent children who all go to school. The couple takes care of the family responsibilities together.

In order to take care of the diverse household responsibilities, Albertine has been selling plastics and fabric by the distribution system for about ten years. At the same time, Albertine sells shoes. Albertine gets her supplies in a market of Bénin. 

In seeking to satisfy her customers and to grow her turnover and her income, Albertine is requesting a fourth loan from ALIDé together with the other members of the Mahudjro group. The first three loans were well repaid.

loans.use: to buy plastics, fabric and shoes.

loans.name: Asha

texts.en: Asha, 23 years old, is married and has one child. She describes herself as determined and passionate in her work. She sells clothes such as t-shirts, children's wear and curtains along a busy road. She has been in this business for three years. She describes her business challenge to be stiff competition within the area. She will be using the loan of Kes15,000 to buy more clothes to sell. Asha hopes and dreams of running a boutique in the next five years.

loans.use: To buy more clothes.

loans.name: Emma

texts.en:
Emma is married. She is 53 years old, and resides in Malibangcao, Clarin, Misamis Occidental, Philippines. Emma owns and operates farmland, planting and harvesting corn for sale to earn a living and she has been in this business for five years. Each month, she earns 3,000 PHP from this business.

She has requested a loan of 5,000 PHP to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise. In 2011, Emma joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. In the future, Emma wants to make improvements to her house and to improve her family's general living conditions.

loans.use: to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise

loans.name: Abiyemeje Group

texts.en: Marie jeanne is a group leader; aged 36 years. She is married with 7 children aged between 5 and 12 years. The group is called ABIZERWA means “THE TRUSTED ” in English. They sell different products and they wish to expand their business for changing their better future. She sells foodstuffs and has been running in a business for 5 years. With the loan, she would like to buy more rice, banana and cassava and for sale. The profits from the business will be used to pay school fees of her children and pay medical insurance.

loans.use: to buy more rice, banana and cassava and for sale.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To improve on the agric farm

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Rosalind would like to buy a dairy cow.

loans.name: Maryuri

texts.en:
Maryuri has 2 years’ experience with her business of selling cosmetics. She used to work in a clothing store, but she was laid-off. A friend encouraged her to sell these cosmetic products. She works everyday of the week from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m.

Maryuri wants to use the loan to invest in her business. By having a bigger investment her earnings will be bigger as well. She also wants to sell other articles like clothing.

Maryuri is a widower. She is 30 years old and she has a 14 year old daughter. Her husband died of tonsil cancer 8 years ago. She is now renting a house where she lives with her daughter who is in school. Maryuri’s mother in law who is abroad helps her with the needs of her granddaughter. Her mother and sister are always looking after her and help her when needed. She has been able to pull through with her own work. With this business, she hopes to able to save enough to buy a small house.

Translated from Spanish by Ana Gabriela Clark, Kiva Volunteer.

Maryuri tiene una experiencia de 2 años con su negocio de venta de cosméticos. Ella trabajaba en un local de venta de ropa, del cual la liquidaron. Por iniciativa de una amiga la impulsa a vender estos productos. Trabaja todos los días de la semana en horario de 9 a.m. hasta las 5 p.m.

Maryuri desea el crédito para poder invertir en su negocio. Al hacer una mayor inversión sus ganancias van a hacer mejores. Además desea poder vender otros artículos como son las prendas de vestir.

Maryuri es viuda. Tiene 30 años y una hija de 14 años. Su esposo falleció hace ocho años de un cáncer a las amígdalas. Ella actualmente alquila y vive solo con su hija la que estudia. Su suegra que esta en el exterior le ayuda con lo que necesita su nieta. Además tiene la ayuda de su madre y hermana las cuales están pendientes de lo que necesita. Ella con su trabajo ha logrado salir adelante con su familia. Espera con su negocio poder ir ahorrando y tener su casita propia.

loans.use: Buy cosmetics and clothing

loans.name: Maria Del Carmen

texts.en:
Mrs. Maria del Carmen has been selling shoes from catalogs for more than four years, after she suffered a work related accident and could no longer perform her normal job. Through sales she found a way to continue obtaining income for family. She has two adolescent sons that help her in her business, charging customers and delivering the products. She also has a small daughter. The wellbeing of her children is Maria’s greatest driving force to work hard every day despite her disability.

In order to increase her sales and provide a good service, Maria is requesting a loan of $325 that she will use to buy merchandise to fulfill the orders of her customers. She commits to repay the loan in four months. Your help will contribute to the development of this business, and to increase the quality of life of his family. Please help them out; they will be very thankful.

Translated from Spanish by Ramón F. Kolb, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Maria del Carmen se dedica a la venta de calzado por catálogo desde hace más de cuatro años, a raíz de que sufrió un accidente laboral se fracturó la cadera y quedó incapacitada para realizar el trabajo que normalmente desempeñaba, así fue como encontró en las ventas una forma de seguir obteniendo ingresos para su familia, ella tiene dos hijos adolescentes que la apoyan en su negocio en cobranza y entrega de lo productos, también tiene una pequeña hija. El bienestar de sus hijos es el motivo más grande que tiene Maria para salir a trabajar arduamente día a día, a pesar de su incapacidad.

Para poder incrementar sus ventas y brindar un buen servicio Maria solicita un préstamo por $ 325 dólares que utilizará en la compra de mercancía con la que podrá surtir los pedidos que tiene de sus clientes, ella se compromete a devolver esta cantidad en 4 meses. Con tu ayuda contribuyes al desarrollo de este negocio y a mejorar la calidad de vida de esta familia, decídete a apoyarlos, ellos te lo agradecen mucho.

loans.use: to buy merchandise

loans.name: Blanca

texts.es:
Blanca V. is 43 years old and happily married for 20 years to Lucio Gonzalez. Lucio is an agricultural engineer. They have four children, 19, 15, 10 and 6 years old who all attend school.

Blanca is a retired teacher, and these days she has a store which she started in 2006. It is strategically located in the municipal market in the city of Caaguazu, where she has an established customer base. The income from this helps her husband with the education of their children so that they can all finish school and get degrees.

The loan she is requesting is to buy merchandise for her store, such as hoes, thermoses, sawdust, brooms and cement. With this she will be able to expand her stock of merchandise, and offer her customers better service and better quality.

La Sra. Blanca V. de 43 años de edad, está felizmente casada, desde hace 20 años con el Sr. Lucio Gonzalez de 44 años de edad, es Ingeniero Agrónomo y se encuentra ejerciendo tal profesión, tienen 4 hijos de 19, 15, 10 y 6 años respectivamente, quienes estan estudiando. Doña Blanca es profesora jubilada y actualmente se encuentra al frente de una ferreteria que se había iniciado en el año 2006, dicha ferreteria se encuentra estratégicamente ubicada en el Mercado Municipal de la ciudad de Caaguazú, donde ya cuenta con su clientela bien formada, lo el ingreso que obtiene ayuda a su esposo para la educacion de sus hijos para que todos puedan obtener un titulo universitario El crédito que solicita es para la compra de mercaderias, táles como: Azadas, termos, hojas de sierra, escoba de jardín y cemento. De este modo aumentará su stock de mercaderias y ofrecerá a sus clientes un mejor servicio con mayor calidad.

Translated by Kiva volunteer, Emily Charnes

loans.use: To buy merchandise for her store

loans.name: Siti Aminah

texts.id:
Siti started to sell food 10 years ago. She lives with husband and two children, including grandchild. Siti has a small food stall in front of her home. This food stall is where she sells food, like: Rujak, tipat cantok (local food types), and other small food. Per day her gross income is about Rp150,000.00 (about US$16.50), with expenses of Rp 50,000.00 (about $5.50)/day. The raw materials she bought in the market herself - not far from home. Although 54 years old, her energy to earn for husband and herself is still high. Her husband is sick - so he could not work - plus his sight is blurred. In their age, she is not expecting much; she hopes her business could help her provide enough income for her husband's and her own needs. Loan from Dinari will be used to increase business capital.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Gwan Liong Ang, Kiva volunteer.

Siti mulai usaha jual makanan ini sekitar 10 tahun yang lalu. Dia tinggal bersama suami dan anaknya yang kedua – termasuk cucunya. Siti mempunyai warung kecil di depan rumahnya. Warung inilah tempatnya menjual makanan, antara lain : rujak, tipat cantok dan makanan kecil lainnya. Per hari penghasilan kotornya mencapai Rp 150.000,00 dengan biaya hidup Rp 50.000,00/hari. Bahan baku untuk jualan dibelinya sendiri di pasar – tidak jauh dari tempat tinggalnya. Walau sudah berumur 54 tahun, semangatnya untuk menafkahi suami dan diri sendiri masih besar. Suaminya dalam kondisi sakit – jadi tidak bisa bekerja - ditambah lagi dengan penglihatannya yang mulai kabur. Di usianya ini dia tidak berharap banyak memang ; dia hanya berharap usaha yang dilakukannya ini bisa membantunya untuk mencukupi kebutuhan suami dan kebutuhannya sendiri. Pinjaman yang diperoleh akan dia pakai untuk menambah modal usaha.

loans.use:
To buy rice, fruits, and spices

Membeli beras, buah dan bumbu.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Improve her family and home

loans.name: Eusebia

texts.en:
‘Pinchón’ – as she is affectionately called by her friends and neighbors – is a hyperactive, strong, and hard-working woman. She is thirty-three years old and she has three children. To earn a living and take care of her children, she sells pants, blue jeans, and underwear to women of her community.

Her contagious laugh, her kindness toward the customers, and her ‘crazy’ jokes help her cultivate good relations with people, keeping the present customers loyal and attracting new ones.

Eusebia explains that she would like to rent a locale before long so that she can run her business more easily. With her loan, she will buy clothing in bulk in Santo Domingo, the capital. That way, Eusebia will reduce the frequent trips outside her community to get goods. She will increase her income and keep working for the sake of her family.

loans.use: Purchase clothing in bulk for her small business

loans.name: Ziver

texts.en: Zivar lives in the suburbs of Sumgait with her family – her husband and two children. She has been engaged in business for 10 years now. She specializes in selling assorted food stuffs and sales have been on the rise recently. Zivar applied to Sumgait branch of Normicro as she needs to buy a cash machine for her shop. This is a requirement of the tax authorities as she has to use her own money for the turnover capital. For that she needs $500 for 12 months.

loans.use: To buy a cash machine

loans.name: Upendo

texts.en:
This is 44 year-old Upendo M.. She is married with four children, aged between 13 and 24.

In 2006 Upendo established a grain business. Upendo has already received and successfully repaid two loans from SELFINA, and now requires a new loan in order to purchase additional stocks of rice, maize, and beans in bulk. She thanks you for your support.

SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback facility as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women.

loans.use: To purchase additional stocks of rice, maize, and beans in bulk.

loans.name: Lucia's Group

texts.es:
Teresa, Lucia, and Norma have been members of the Sonrisa (Smile) Community Bank for 1 year, 1 year and 8 months respectively.

Teresa is a 50 year old married woman with four children. Teresa is a traditional artist and shapes alabaster stones. She sells the stones in a shop in Ayacucho and both at the national and international level.

Lucia is a 44 year old married woman with four children. Lucia travels to the regional fairs three times a week to purchase grains and cereals. These she sells in the different markets of Ayacucho.

Norma is a 24 year old woman and shares her home with her one daughter. Norma recently opened a stall in the Santa Clara market in which she sells hardware & tools.

Teresa, Lucia and Norma need a loan of S./1,200, S./1,400 and S./600 respectively. These funds will be used to purchase alabaster stone, tools, corn, barley, wheat, locks and nails.

Teresa, Lucia and Norma’s dreams are to grow their businesses, increase their capital, own their own shops and homes and provide their children with good educations.

Translated from Spanish by Casey Unrein, Kiva volunteer.

Teresa, Lucia y Norma pertenece al Banco Comunal Sonrisa hace 1 año, 1 año, 8 meses respectivamente.

Teresa es casada, tiene 50 años y 4 hijos, Teresa es artesana en tallado de piedra de Huamanga (alabastro), sus trabajos lo vende a nivel nacional e internacional, además tiene un puesto en el mercado artesanal de la ciudad de Ayacucho.

Por otro lado Lucia es casada, tiene 44 años y 4 hijos, Lucia viaja a las ferias de la región 3 veces por semana, donde compra cereales y lo vende en los diferentes mercados de la ciudad de Ayacucho.

Mientras que Norma es conviviente, tiene 24 años y 1 hija, Norma tiene un puesto en el mercado Santa Clara donde vende artículos de ferretería, actividad que recién ha iniciado.

Teresa, Lucia y Norma necesitan un préstamo de 1200 soles, 1400 soles, 600 soles, dinero que será invertido en la compra de piedra de Huamanga, herramientas, maíz, cebada, trigo, candados, clavos.

Los sueños de Teresa, Lucia y Norma son mejorar su negocio, tener más capital, puesto propio, casa propia y que sus hijos tengan una buena educación.

loans.use: Teresa, Lucia and Norma need a loan of S./1,200, S./1,400 and S./600 respectively.  These funds will be used to purchase alabaster stone, tools, corn, barley, wheat, locks and nails.

loans.name: Tran Thi

texts.vi:
Mrs Trần Thị Thơ is 50 years old. She joined TYM fund 5 years ago. She lives in Lương Bằng with her husband and their 3 children. Their children are all adults now. She raises pigs and grow fruits. Her land is filled with dates, guavas, apples ... There are 2 crops a year. The revenue from the sales of the pigs and the fruit is a few thousands USD a year. She is a hard working woman and her husband is very supportive of her. With the help of her husband and her children, she has never been late in her payment. This time she is requesting a loan of 625 USD to buy new fruit plants and pig mash.

Translated from Vietnamese by Khang Ho-Si, Kiva volunteer.

Chị Trần Thị Thơ, 50 tuổi, là thành viên năm thứ 5 của Quỹ Tình thương. Chị sống cùng chồng và 3 con tại thị trấn Lương Bằng. Các con chị đều trên 18 tuổi. Công việc chính của chị là chăn nuôi lợn và trồng cây ăn quả. Vườn của chị chủ yếu trồng các loại táo, na, ổi ... mỗi năm cho thu hoạch 1 đến 2 vụ. Thu nhập hàng năm từ vườn cây và chăn nuôi lên đến vài nghìn USD. Nhờ cố gắng của bản thân cộng với sự hỗ trợ tích cực của chồng con nên chị Thơ luôn tham gia sinh hoạt và hoàn trả đầy đủ cho Quỹ. Vòng vốn này chị xin vay 625USD mua thêm một số giống cây mới và mua thức ăn gia súc.

loans.use: Buy fruit plants and pig mash

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Agnes A. is 32, married, and has two children, aged 7 and 5. She owns and operates a little grocery shop selling items like rice, evaporated milk, canned foods and drinks, assorted cooking oil, frozen beef, chicken, and fish. She wants to use the loan to buy more rice, canned foods and drinks, milk, etc. to expand her business. She believes that with increased income, she would be better able to provide a decent accommodation for her family.

Agnes belongs to the community group called Determination Trust Group. In this group, members guarantee for one another as social collateral to access a loan and peer pressure to repay the loan.

loans.use: To buy rice, canned foods, drinks, milk, etc. to expand her inventory

loans.name: Santos

texts.es:
Mr.Santos I. dedicates himself to the business of farming and livestock in the city of Leon in the municipality of El Sauce. He distinguishes himself by having a lot of experience when it comes to cultivation and livestock. He supports his four children and also provides for their education. It is important to note that thanks to his hard work he has been able to give his children his support so that they can get ahead.

He is seeking the support of Ceprodel with the goal of obtaining a loan that will allow him to purchase steers to raise so that he may sell them to his clients. Both he and his loving family will benefit from this loan.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy M., Kiva Volunteer.

El señor Santos I. se dedica al negocio agropecuario en la ciudad de León en el municipio de El Sauce. Se destaca por tener amplia experiencia en el trato con el cultivo y los animales del ganado. Es padre de cuatro hijos en la obligación de mantener y proporcionarles sus respectivos estudios. Es de importancia destacar que gracias a sus esfuerzos ha logrado brindarles su apoyo para que estos salgan adelante.

Hoy en día busca el poyo en Ceprodel con el objetivo de obtener un crédito que le permita comprar de novillos para desarrollarlos y cuando crezcan venderlos a sus clientes. Con este crédito se beneficia tanto él como su amada familia.

loans.use: Purchase of livestock.

loans.name: Heriberto

texts.es:
Mr. Heriberto O. has spent several years in the business of agriculture where he grows basic grains and coffee and stands out as a small producer in the town of Condega where he resides.

It is important to stress that he is a man whose responsibility is to provide for his family by giving them all that is necessary for their development. Despite the many difficulties he has faced, he has managed to succeed thanks to the support provided by Ceprodel which has provided him with loans that he's been able to use in order to improve his farm's crops. Once again he has gone to Ceprodel and applied for a loan with which to improve his business through the purchase of a solar panel/module, which in turn will assist him with the growing of basic grains.

Translated from Spanish by Mayra Gould, Kiva volunteer.

El señor Heriberto C. O. se dedica desde hace varios años al negocio de agricultura cultivando granos básicos y café destacándose como pequeño productor en el municipio de Condega donde reside.

Es de importancia destacar que es un caballero con la responsabilidad de mantener su familia brindándole las condiciones necesarias para su desarrollo. A pesar de las múltiples dificultades que ha atravesado, ha logrado salir adelante gracias al apoyo brindado por Ceprodel el cual le ha otorgado créditos que los ha utilizado para mejorar su actividad de agricultura. Una vez más acude a Ceprodel para obtener un crédito con el cual mejorar su actividad por medio de la compra de un modulo solar e inversión en la siembra de los granos básicos.

loans.use: Purchase of a solar panel / module to aid in the cultivation of grain. (Compra de un modulo solar para los cultivos)

loans.name: Mujeres Solidarias Group

texts.es:
The group called Mujeres Solidarias formed in the month of November, 2006. This committee formed thanks to Idalina J., who came to a talk and was interested in the program. She motivated her neighbors to participate in the program. The group is centered in the center of the city of Itá.

The group has now worked with the Fundación Paraguaya (this microcredit organization) for two years. All of them have been adhered to the program and this has brought them the opportunity to get loans much more easily and it is also important to point out that they value the loan and they demonstrate excellent repayment behavior. They are very talented and and united, participating in meetings twice monthly. Also they do extra activities in order to gather the funds to solve any eventuality that might happen to the committee.

The group is made up of a total of 15 industrious women who do various activities. They want a new loan that they will invest according to the activity of each member.

Florencia Báez will use her loan to buy fabric and thread to make and embroider items to wear. Aida R. will buy wallets, necklaces, and other articles to sell. Lucia R., Valentina E., Mercedes A., Teresa R., Julia G., Idalina J., Maris H. and María Teresa N. have stores where they will invest their loans in the purchase of rice, sugar, yerba mate (an herbal tea), flour, vermicelli, cleaning supplies, etc.

Nilda C. wants to buy sweets as she is in charge of a school canteen. Gloria G. sells clothes and she wants to acquire winter clothing stock. Emiliana A. will buy coal to sell.

The last two are Liz O. who will invest her loan to buy fruits and vegetables for her business, and Francisca B. who also sells clothing and therefore the loan would be destined to buy winter clothing.

Translated from Spanish by Jessica Kaminsky, Kiva Volunteer.

El Grupo denominado Mujeres Solidarias, se conformó en el mes de noviembre del año 2.006, dicho comité se conformó mediante la señora Idalina J. quién participó de una charla y se interesó por el programa motivando a sus vecinas a participar del mismo. El Comité “Mujeres Solidarias” se encuentra localizado en el centro de la cuidad de Itá.

El grupo ya lleva trabajando más de 2 años con la Fundación Paraguaya, todas ellas se encuentran muy conformes con el programa ya que les brinda la oportunidad de obtener con mucha facilidad créditos, así mismo cabe destacar que valoran el préstamo y lo demuestran con el excelente comportamiento de pago. Son muy cumplidas y unidas, semanalmente participan de sus reuniones, además realizan actividades extras para la recaudación de fondos para solventar cualquier eventualidad que surja dentro del comité.

Está integrado por un total de 15 laboriosas mujeres que realizan diversas actividades. Ellas desean un nuevo crédito que lo invertirán según la actividad de cada integrante:

Florencia Báez destino su crédito a la compra de telas de Ao o'i e hilos para la confección y bordado de prendas de vestir. Aida R. a la compra de carteras, bijouterie, y artículos de mercería. Lucia R., Valentina E., Mercedes A., Teresa R., Julia G., Idalina J., Maris H. y María Teresa N. poseen despensas por lo que invertirán sus crédito en la compra de arroz, azúcar, yerba mate, harina, fideos, articulas de limpieza, etc.

Nilda C. desea comprar golosinas ya que ella es encargada de una de cantina escolar, Gloria G. vende ropas por lo que desea adquirir ropas de invierno, Emiliana A. comprará carbón para la venta.

Las últimas dos son Liz O. que invertirá el crédito para la compra de frutas y verduras para su negocio y Francisca B. que también vende ropas por lo que el crédito será destinado en la compra ropas para invierno.

loans.use: To buy fabric, needles, clothes, wallets, jewelry, rice, sugar, flour, vermicelli, cleaning supplies, coal, fruits and vegetables.

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.en: Mrs. Nguyen Thi K. joined TYM in 2002. For the first loan cycle, she borrowed VND 1 million to raise pigs. At present, her family's main source of income is pig raising and farming. Besides, every month she receives financial assistance from her children. Owing to that, she repays her loans very well. For the next loan cycle, she wants to borrow VND 6 million to raise a cow.

loans.use: buying a cow to raise

loans.name: Salah

texts.en: Salah is a single young man. He is 28 years old and lives with his parents in a village near the city of Baalback in the Bekaa Valley. Salah is a professionA. blacksmith who works nearly every day of the year from 8:00 AM until 6:00 PM. Salah wishes to expand his business and has requested a loan of $1000 to do so.

loans.use: to expand his blacksmith business

loans.name: Julio Cesar

texts.es: El Sr. C. M. habita en la Cmca. La Palma, Tecolostote dedicado al cultivo de arroz, tiene 8 Mzs por esfuerzo propio, atiende de manera personal el establecimiento y manejo del cultivo apoyado por 2 hijos, que despues de estudiar por la mañana se incorporan al trabajo por la tarde.  Su esposa Sandra Mendoza garantiza muy temprano la alimentacion de su hijo para la escuela y su marido al trabajo.  Uno de sus principales problemas es el trillado de su produccion, por lo que tienen que vender  en granza a menor precio, lo que le reduce sus ingresos que son el sosten familiar; a traves de su cooperativa tiene la oportunidad de asociarse para la instalacion de 1 trillo en la comunidad, lo que le garantiza mejores y mayores ingresos, para lo cual requiere el presente financiamiento y asi alcanzar su sueño de ser parte asociativa de esta futura empresa productiva.
texts.en:
Mr. C. M. lives in the La Palma neighborhood of Tecolostote. He cultivates rice for a living. He has 8 Mzs (manzanas—about 5.6 hectares) of rice from his own efforts. He personally attends to the establishment and managing of the crops with the help of two of his children who work in the rice fields in the evening after attending school in the morning. His wife, Sandra Mendoza, prepares food her children and husband early in the morning. One of his main problems is threshing the rice, which is why he has to sell rice husks at a lower price, and this in turn reduces his earnings—his family’s means of support. He has the opportunity of becoming an associate in his co-op so that they can install a rice huller in the community, which guarantees better and greater earnings. For this reason, he needs this loan so that he can realize his dream of becoming a part of this future company.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Contribute 30% towards construction of rice huller for La Peña rice

loans.name: Herlosita

texts.en:
Herlosita is married to Hipolito, a farmer in their village.  Their marriage has been gifted with six children: Gilbert – 34 years old, college undergraduate, working abroad; Bernard – 32 years old, high school graduate; Crisanto – 30 years old, high school graduate; Gerard – 25 years old, college undergraduate, also working abroad; Gersalin – 22 years old, also college undergraduate and Geny – 15 years old, a 3rd year high school student.  Three of their children are already married.  Her family lives in the hilly and peaceful Barangay of San Isidro.  

Herlosita is engaged in farm activities.  However, they lack financial resources to sustain their business so she is asking a loan of PHP10,000.  She intends to utilize the loan to buy their needed farm inputs like fertilizers, seedlings, insecticide and herbicide. Some of the amount will also be used to pay for labor works for those who will help them during the planting period. 

She is proud that despite their old age, she and her husband are continuously helping and supporting each other in reaching their dreams.  They want their farming business to grow in order to generate higher income and provide for the educational needs of their youngest child who is now in high school. They hope that they can provide her educational needs until college and finish her desire course.  

If the loan will be granted to her, Herlosita will no longer borrow from traders and somehow be free from asking credits to them in times of financial needs.

loans.use: To purchase farm inputs like fertilizers, seedlings, insecticide and herbicide and pay additional farm labor

loans.name: Srey's Group

texts.en:
This is a small group of three members, requesting a loan. Mrs. L. grouped the three eligible members and was selected to be leader of the group. She is widowed with two children, one of whom is married. She is a rice farmer who lives in Chamres Village in Siem Reap Province.

This is the third loan for Mrs. L. and the past two loans were repaid on time. To support her family, L. works hard every day to generate revenue; normally she buys rice to stock for re-sale at higher prices. Her business has gone well and now she would like to request a loan to purchase more rice to stock.

The other two members are:

Mrs. L., a rice farmer who needs a loan to buy rice to stock for re-sale;

Mrs. R., a rice farmer who needs a loan to purchase rice to stock to re-sell at a profit.

loans.use: to purchase more rice  to stock

loans.name: Milagros

texts.es:
Hace año y medio Milagros empezó a vender productos de belleza por catalogo. Al inicio empezó vendiendo solo una marca pero con el paso del tiempo se dio cuenta que podía vender más. Es así que se inscribió como consultora de una segunda marca también. Y ahora puede vender más ya que ofrece más variedad a sus clientes.

Antes de tener su pequeño negocio ella se dedicaba por completo a su casa y al cuidado de sus menores hijos de 6 y 4 años. Aunque no le va mal en su trabajo muchas veces le es difícil dejar solos a sus hijos para poder ofrecer sus productos de casa en casa y cobrar a sus compradores. Por este motivo, esta pensando en abrir una tienda de abarrotes en su casa.

Por ahora las ganancias de su trabajo las usa para cubrir algunos gastos básicos de su casa. Su esposo trabaja como maestro de obras y también se encarga de ayudar en los gastos de alimentos y educación de sus hijos.
texts.en:
One and a half years ago, Milagros started selling beauty products by catalog. At the beginning, she was just selling a single brand, but over time she realized she could sell more. So Milagros registered as a consultant with a second brand too. And now, Milagros can sell more, because she offers more choices to her customers. Before starting her small business, Milagros was a full-time housewife, focused on taking care of her home, and her younger children, ages 6 and 4. Although Milagros does okay with her business, it is often difficult to leave her children alone while going door-to-door to sell her products and collect payment. For this reason, she is thinking about opening up a grocery store in her home. For now, the profits from her work are used to cover some basic household costs. Her husband works as a construction foreman and is also responsible for contributing to the cost of food and education for their children.

Translated from Spanish by Scott Lucas, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase the beauty products that she sells.

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose A. is thirty-five years old. She is married and has given birth to four children, all girls. She says currently, one of them is in senior high school, another in junior high school while the rest are in primary school. Her husband is a cocoa and palm farmer. She lives with her family in an old family house at Simpa. Simpa is a small farming community which is a few kilometers from Tarkwa in the Western Region of Ghana. Most of the inhabitants combine farming with other economic activities.

Rose sells maize and groundnuts. She buys bags of maize and groundnuts from the farmers in her community and nearby villages. She says food vendors come from the big cities to buy from her. She also sells in the local market and treks to nearby markets. Rose has been in business for three years. She wants to buy maize/groundnuts on a larger scale so that she can supply them to the increasing number of her customers and increase her profit. Rose desires to help her children climb the academic ladder to higher levels.

loans.use: To procure maize and groundnuts for re-sale

loans.name: Nancy

texts.en:
Nancy is a 28-year-old mother of three children aged 5, 3 and 2. She is raising them alone in Nyamasaria slum where she lives. She runs a small kiosk where she sells ice-cream, soda and other small items. She will use this loan to maintain her kiosk and buy more stock.

Nancy recently joined the K-MET volunteer Community Health Worker (CHW) group in Kisumu, Kenya. As a CHW, she will be trained by K-MET and will begin visiting members of her community who are sick with a variety of illnesses. Her work will include distributing Nutriflour (a vitamin enriched flour produced by K-MET) to malnourished patients, providing reproductive health education, referring patients to local clinics and hospitals, and providing basic health care.

loans.use: To purchase food stock

loans.name: Arnaldo

texts.es:
El señor Arnaldo O. tiene 33 años, está casado, y tiene 2 hijos. El es propietario de un vehiuculo Toyota y se dedica al servcio de taxi. La misma esta ubicada en Barrio San Miguel de la ciudad de Caacupe.  La parada donde el trabaja cuenta con cinco taxi y dueños diferentes.

El cliente comenta que el servicio que realiza es por todo cordillera pero en en la ciudad que mas presta servicio es Caacupe y Atyra. Tambien alega que con los préstamos que le otorgó la Fundación Paraguaya pudo pagar el servicio de reparacion por su vehiculo. Esto hizo que pudiera mantener su clientela ya formada y asi tambien llegar a mas  clientes.

Su objetivo a muy corto plazo es comprarce un vehiculo en mejores condiciones para asi darles mayor comodida a sus clientes.
texts.en:
Mr. Arnaldo O. is 33 years old, married, and has two children. He owns a Toyota and works as a taxi driver in the San Miguel district of the city of Caacupe. The taxi stop where he works has five different taxis drivers. He shares that he works over the whole range of land, but in the city he mainly works in Caacupe and Atyra. He claims that with the previous loans from Fundación Paraguaya he was able to pay for repairs on his vehicle, allowing him to maintain his client base he had already formed and also obtain more customers. His short term goal is to buy himself a car in better condition to provide greater comfort for his customers.

Translated from Spanish by Emily Meinecke, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To repair his car

loans.name: Bujinlham

texts.en:
Bujinlham L. is 69, married, and the mother of one daughter, Dariimaa, who is attending elementary school. Her family lives in a "ger" (Nomadic Mongolian tent) in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Bujinlham retired in 1992, so to increase her family’s income she runs a tailoring business, making traditional Mongolian clothing, shoes and crafts containing many kinds of beautiful traditional decorative patterns.

Bujinlham requests a loan to buy raw materials to increase her business inventory. She says, "With the profit, I will save for my only daughter's future house".

loans.use: To buy raw materials.

loans.name: Inna

texts.en:
Inna is married with one child. She sells tights and socks at the central market in Melitopol city and has been in this business for 12 years. Inna is a very entrepreneurial and open person. She knows her business well enough and what kind of inventories to purchase. Moreover, the good location of her kiosk also helps the business.

Inna would like a loan of 7,200 UAH to purchase more tights and socks for the coming season. She hopes to receive more income and replace old home equipment in her house.

loans.use: To purchase more tights and socks for sale.

loans.name: Jorenda

texts.en: "We started tilling a 1-hectare (2.5-acre) farm and have benefited much from it. We are able to provide food for our family and send our children to school. My husband and I dream of buying another farm. This is to grow our income to support our family‘s growing needs,” says Jorenda N., 39-year-old mother of four children. She would like to ask for a loan of Php 10,000 from CEVI. She will use the loan to buy complete fertilizers, herbicides and seed. She is also interested in venturing into other lines of business. CEVI helps small businesses to grow. It provides its clients not only with credit, but with training and insurance coverage as well.

loans.use: To purchase complete fertilizers, herbicides and seed

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase stock of African traditional cloth in bulk.

loans.name: Karla Auxiliadora

texts.es:
En la ciudad de Managua, específicamente en el Mercado Mayoreo, es un lugar donde muchas personas llegan a realizar sus compras a diario y es allí donde la señora Karla V. tiene su propio negocio de venta de ropa el cual es comercializada por ella misma y ofrecida a sus clientes.

Actualmente, la señora Karla ha acudido a Ceprodel porque tiene una necesidad como lo es la de adquirir un crédito para la compra de la ropa. Es por este motivo que espera muy confiadamente en que Ceprodel le brindará un crédito para salir adelante y de esta manera mejorará su condición económica.
texts.en:
Mrs. Karla V. has her own business selling cloths in the city of Managua at a Wholesale Market, where many people go to shop everyday. Ms. Karla is asking for a loan to Ceprodel for the purchase of clothing. She is very confident in getting the support from Ceprodel to succeed and improve her economic status.

Translated from Spanish by Adriana Pierce, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Benkadi 3 De Toura  Nabitokan Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe BENKADI 3 est composé de femmes mariées du village de Toura Nabitokan de la ville de SAN région de SEGOU (quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali) qui vivent dans des familles traditionnelles. Elles ont en moyenne 47 ans, au moins 4 enfants et  cultivent  de l’arachide. 
Dans le souci de rentabiliser leurs exploitations agricoles, les membres du groupe BENKADI 3 de  Toura  Nabitokan ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant 2 ans. Après avoir correctement remboursé  le  prêt précédent, elles sont à leur deuxième prêt de campagne.
Le prêt actuel sera utilisé pour acheter, une quantité suffisante de semence d’arachide, des petits matériels et des intrants pour la culture, exclusivement  au grand marché de Kimparana  ville. Après l’hivernage, les récoltes sont stockées pendant un certain  temps pour qu’elles aient de la valeur avant d’être vendues  au grand marché de Kimparana et  dans les  marchés  environnants, en détail (souvent en gros), au comptant  à une clientèle venant généralement des grandes villes.
Les membres du groupe BENKADI 3 comptent réaliser chacune, après l’écoulement de leurs produits agricoles, un bénéfice de 30 000 à 25 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé  pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt  et les dépenses courantes de la famille.
texts.en:
The BENKADI 3 group is made of married women of the Toura Nabitokan village, in the city of SAN (Ségou Region, fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali), who live in traditional families. They average 47 years of age, and have at least 4 children. They grow peanuts.

Eager to make their agricultural businesses profitable, the members of the BENKADI 3 group decided to join the loan program of Kiva's partner, Soro Yiriwaso, two years ago. After having repaid the previous loan without problems, they are now seeking their second farming loan.

This loan will be used to buy, exclusively at the grand market in Kimparana, a sufficient quantity of peanut seeds, small materials, and fertilizers for the fields. After the rainy season, the crops are stored for a while to gain market value, before being sold at the grand market in Kimparara and in the surrounding markets, retail (often wholesale) and for cash, to a clientele usually coming from the larger cities.

After selling their products, the members of the BENKADI 3 group count on turning a profit of XOF 30000 to 25000 (ca US$ 65 to 55) each, to be used to repay the loan and to pay for the daily expenses of their families.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy peanut seeds, small materials, and fertilizers for the fields

loans.name: Silverward Mugera Mary Group

texts.en: M. Mary has been operating a clothing business for two years. She is 25 years of age and married with two children, one of whom is in school. She is using this loan to purchase more clothing to add stock to her business. She is a hardworking and inspiring business lady whose dream is to educate her children and enlarge her business.

loans.use: To purchase more clothing

loans.name: Carlos Enoc

texts.es: Carlos Enoc Z. F. tiene 24 años. Es un joven soltero. A pesar de su corta edad le ha gustado trabajar y ganarse el dinero de una manera muy humilde. Hace más de 11 años que se dedica a la venta de comida, por lo que atiende su negocio todos los días. Además Carlos se encarga de la elaboración de tortillas, y con estos pocos ingresos ayuda a su mama y su familia. Anteriormente cuando estaba más pequeño salía a vender sus tortillas de manera ambulante y recorría muchos lugares con el fin de ayuda lo suficiente económicamente a su Mama y más tarde decide establecer una venta de comida en su vivienda. El financiamiento que solicita es para capital de trabajo para la compra de maíz, leña, frijoles, azúcar, aceite entre otras cosas. Su deseo es poseer su propio restaurante.

loans.use: capital de trabajo

loans.name: Absa

texts.fr: Absa C. est une jeune femme de 32 ans, mariée et mère de 6 enfants. Elle fait un commerce de diverses denrées alimentaires. Elle sollicite ce prêt pour renforcer sa boutique en marchandises. Les revenus lui permettront d’assurer les soins de santé et la scolarité de ses enfants.
texts.en:
Absa C. is a young woman, 32 years old, married, and the mother of six children.  She has a business involving diverse foods.  She's requesting this loan to replenish her store with merchandise.  The revenues will enable her to ensure she meets the health care and schooling needs of her children.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Commerce in a variety of foods

loans.name: Rodah Muthoki

texts.en:
Rodah is single and has been operating a boutique business for two years.  Her boutique is in an open air market with diverse activities.

Rodah was introduced to KADET through existing clients and she has no previous credit history. She has applied for a loan which she plans to use to add to her current working capital so that she can buy handbags, ladies tops and shoes from Kampala in Uganda. With the extra profits, Rodah intends to get a wider variety of stock from countries overseas.

Rodah describes herself as focused and determined, and she would like to own a wholesale boutique shop supplying to retailers. 


About KADET:
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: Working capital to add to variety of stock

loans.name: Hugo

texts.en:
Hugo was a driver in his native Ecuador so, when he moved to the States, it was a natural choice to continue in his profession, and he started his own high-occupancy van transportation business in 2000. One of the major costs of a business like Hugo's is constant maintenance of the vehicle fleet. Hugo was able to cover these costs with a credit card, but it was very costly and only a short-term fix.

Hugo used his first loan to do some maintenance on his van, but this loan served another purpose which was building up and improving his credit history. Now Hugo will be taking out a second loan to cover more maintenance costs, and he hopes to buy a second van soon.

Hugo is optimistic that he will be able to expand his business because his ACCION USA loans have improved his credit rating. He says he is grateful because he feels the loans have lifted him up economically, and he is now more financially comfortable than he would have been if he had kept using credit cards. In addition to buying a new van, Hugo wants to continue to keep his vans in great shape so they will stay functional for years to come.

loans.use: To pay for van maintenance and inspection tags

loans.name: Ana Gladys

texts.es: Ana Gladys A. G.  residente del departamento de La Libertad, vive con su esposo quien es comerciante y su hijo de 18 años de edad estudiante. Hace nueve años Ana se inicio en su negocio vendiendo productos por catalogo de manera ambulante, con el transcurso del tiempo y las ganancias producidas por su negocio, Ana logro comprar mercadería para después ser revendida a sus clientes , es así como hoy tiene un pequeño inventario de productos para ofrecer a sus clientes, el deseo de Ana es seguir invirtiendo en negocio, comprando productos que poseen  gran  demanda como los perfumes y otros artículos de uso personal.
texts.en:
Ana Gladys A. G., a resident of the department of La Libertad, lives with her husband, a merchant, and with her 18 year old son, a student. Nine years ago, Ana began selling products through a catalog on an itinerant basis. With the passage of time and the profits produced by her business Ana succeeded in buying merchandise for resale to her customers. Similarly, today she has a small inventory of products on offer to her customers. Ana’s wish is to continue investing in the business, buying products that are in great demand such as perfumes and other articles for personal use.

Translated from Spanish by Richard Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To stock her inventory

loans.name: Doris

texts.en:
Doris is 42 years old, and is married with four children, all of whom are in school. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in a town called Kade. She works to support her husband in providing for the family.

Doris has a palm oil production business. She buys fresh palm nuts from nearby communities, prepares the oil, and supplies it to retailers in her community as well as selling it at the local market. Doris has been in business for five years and wants a loan to procure palm nuts in bulk to expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase palm nuts in bulk

loans.name: Helen

texts.en:
Helen M., from the village of Mambajao, Camiguin, is 35 years old, married and has two school-aged children. To earn a living, Helen makes and sells charcoal made of coco shells in the local community. Engaged in her business for over 10 years, she earns approximately 7000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Helen joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having fully repaid a previous loan of 8000 PHP from HSPFI that was used to acquire additional inventory and working capital, she is requesting a new loan of 11000 PHP, her third, to invest in expanding the business. Helen plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to continue to improve her enterprise.

About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Maria Del Pilar

texts.en:
Maria is 29 years old and has two children, ages 2 and 5. She lives with her partner. 

Maria has had her clothing business for three years. It began as a way for her to help her husband cover the family expenses. Maria primarily sells clothing and cosmetics and will use this loan to buy a large amount of merchandise so that she will have a good inventory to resell. 

This is Maria’s fourth loan from Fundación León 2000 and she will continue to seek loans to finance her business. Maria’s business is still very small and she does not yet have a store to maintain. Maria wants to continue to invest in her business so that it can grow and provide the necessary income for her family. Maria also hopes that her children will grow to have professional careers of their own and that they will be able to meet the challenges that await them in life.

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Evelini

texts.en:
Evelini S. is 25 and married with 3 children.  She owns a business venture, running bingo games.  Evelini has many years of experience in this business.  Evelini needs a loan of WST $1750 to purchase game prizes.  She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 650 tala or US $271 per week) to financially support immediate members of her family.

Evelini joined SPBD.This is her 4th loan with SPBD. SPBD's loans are Evelini's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

The following social metrics for Evelini S. are provided by SPBD*:
Overall Social Metric Score:                1.6 out of 3
Level of Education:                              1.4 out of 3
Level of total Household Income:         1.8 out of 3
Quality of Household Assets:              2.3 out of 3

*SPBD measures the living conditions of each of its borrowers to track her loan progress. The overall social metric score, provided by SPBD, is based upon a number of factors, such as the condition of the house/household assets, health, education, income level, and family reputation. A higher number represents a higher score. For example, a ""3 out of 3"" on education would mean that the borrower has graduated from university; a ""2 out of 3"" = secondary/high-school, and a ""1 out of 3"" would mean that the borrower is uneducated.

For more information on this score, please see SPBD's partner page at: http://partners.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=15

About SPBD
In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD and since then, it has expanded from the main island of Upolu in Samoa to Savaii, as well as Tonga. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based upon the Grameen Bank lending method.

Please join SPBD's lending team on KIVA to receive on-the-spot updates on SPBD: http://www.kiva.org/community/viewTeam?team_id=8375

loans.use: to purchase bingo game prizes such as sacks of  rice, flour, onions, powder, soap and many more.

loans.name: Conny

texts.en:
Conny K. is a 33-year-old married mother of one son, Kevin Uhuru. She lives with her husband, Lennox, a businessman in Kilifi, a coastal town in Kenya. Conny runs a passenger service transport business in Kilifi and has been in the business for 11 years now. Apart from that, she also keeps dairy cattle as a secondary business and this enables her to earn more income from the sale of milk.

Conny joined KADET recently and is now borrowing her first loan. She plans to purchase a new dairy cow and to purchase some spare parts for her passenger service vehicle. Her matatu (van) plies the Malindi-Kilifi route and has been doing well.

In the future, she hopes to send her son to a better school and diversify her business further.

loans.use: To purchase a new dairy cow and spare parts for her matatu.

loans.name: Hikmat

texts.en: Hikmat N. is a young man who is married and has a child. Hikmat is 33 years old and with his family lives in the Fuzuli region. He has been in this business for six years. Now Hikmat needs a loan of 2000 AZN to buy four calves to improve his business.

loans.use: To buy four calves

loans.name: Derma Yesenia

texts.es:
Derma G. de 35 años, vive en una zona periurbana en la Perimetral de Guayaquil, es divorciada pero tiene una hija de 2 años.

Derma empezó con un capital pequeño que le presto su papa. Compro cremas y ropa poco para tener su propio negocio y así fue incrementando su capital para tener ahora un local de venta de ropa y perfumes.

Ella trabaja desde muy temprano vendiendo cremas a $ 17, blusas a $ 8, perfumes desde $ 16. Uno de los inconvenientes que tiene es la delincuencia que hay en su sector. 

Con el préstamo quiere comprar ropa, perfumes para que su negocio este mas surtido. En el futuro quiere tener más vitrinas y perchas para mejorar su negocio.
texts.en:
Derma G. is 35 years old and lives in a periurban district along the Perimetral Highway of Guayaquil. She is divorced and has a two year old daughter.

Derma started her business using a loan from her father. She bought crèmes and a few articles of clothing to stock her business. Over time, she increased her capital and now has a store where she sells clothes and perfumes.

She begins work very early selling crèmes for $17, blouses for $8, and perfumes for $16. One of the challenges she faces is the amount of crime that occurs in the area. With this loan, she will purchase clothes and perfumes to keep her business stocked. In the future, she hopes to acquire more display cases and clothing racks to improve her business.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase clothing & perfumes

loans.name: Nicanora

texts.en:
Nicanora V. is a 44-year-old married woman who lives in Brgy Cubay, La Carlota City, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating a ready-to-wear clothing business and managing a sugarcane farm. Nicanora’s husband helps her in managing the businesses, especially with the farm. They have 5 children with ages between 14 to 27 years old - some of them are working and the others are currently going to school.

Nicanora joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2006 in the hope that she would be able to help her husband improve the quality of life of their family. With the help of her loans from NWTF-PD she has been able to increase their family income by engaging in her ready-to-wear clothing business and managing their sugarcane farm. Now she earns an average monthly income of Php 16,000 from her business activities.

Nicanora is a member in good standing. Her previous loan of Php 18,000 was used to fund operations of her ready-to-wear business that has been operating for 27 years and for her sugarcane farm.  This had a positive impact in both the business and the family’s living conditions. Now she is borrowing her 8th loan, in the amount of Php 19,500, which she intends to use for her businesses. Nicanora is working hard to achieve her dreams and aspirations for her family, which is to provide them with a brighter future and a more comfortable life.

About NWTF:

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional working capital

loans.name: Sabah

texts.en:
Sabah is a 50-year-old married woman with two children. In 1980, she started running a tailoring business from her home to help her husband, having had their two children, to help raise them. She offers all types of sewing services. She makes all kind of clothes as well as doing repairs. All her clients say that she is very hardworking and active in her work. She has a lot of experience in this occupation and her business is well kept. 

Today, Sabah is requesting to borrow $1,000 to purchase a newly developed sewing machine in order to expand her business activity and to be able to deliver her services faster to her clients.

loans.use: To purchase a new sewing machine

loans.name: Lysel

texts.en:
Lysel R. is from the village of Z-3, Lumbia Cagayan De Oro City. She is 39 years-old and married with seven school-aged children. Lysel owns and operates a specialized retail business selling beauty products such as soap and other such products in the local community. Lysel has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month.

In April 2009, Lysel joined Kiva partner HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lysel has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. Lysel is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Lysel from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

location.town: Z-3, Lumbia, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Florence

texts.en:
Florence is 38 years old and married with four children who go to school. She runs a retail shop and also practices small-scale farming in her rural home to earn a living. She sells household goods, plastics and cereals in her shop. She also receives extra income from her husband’s salary, he being employed as a teacher.

Florence saves her money with her group in Faulu Kenya called Kyeni Ngoleni which guarantees loans made to its members. She hopes to grow her business to a wholesale operation and also renovate her house in the future. She has requested a loan of Kes 70,000 from Faulu Kenya to add to her stock of sugar, flour and cooking fat.

loans.use: To add to her stock of sugar, flour and cooking fat

loans.name: Trương

texts.en:
T. Trương Thị (20203050001) is a 53-year-old female living in the town of Yên Phong - Bắc Ninh.  She is married and has three adult children.  To make a living, T. operates a family member's business raising cattle for sale.  T. has been engaged in this business for over 12 years and earns approximately 5,000,000 VND a month from these activities.


In 2009, T. joined SEDA to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  T. has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,152,000 VND from SEDA.  This previous loan was used to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in the future.  T. is now requesting a new loan of 7,840,000, which will be used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies.  The loan will be the second loan taken out by T. from SEDA.  T. plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.


About SEDA:

The mission of SEDA (Center of Small Enterprise Development Assistance) is to provide microfinance services to the low income and disadvantaged people in rural areas of Hanoi and the Northern provinces of Vietnam.


*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.


T. Trương Thị (20203050001) là 53 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy sống ở thành phố Yên Phong - Bắc Ninh.  Cô ấy đã lập gia đình và có 3 trẻ ở độ tuổi trưởng thành.  Để kiếm sống, T. Tham gia công việc kinh doanh của gia đình.  Công việc kinh doanh hoạt động tại lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc.  Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ chăn nuôi gia súc để bán.  T. thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 12 năm.  Từ các hoạt động này, T. kiếm được khoảng 5.000.000 VND một tháng.


Vào 2009, T. đã tham gia SEDA để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải T.  sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy.  T. đề nghị khoản vay lần đầu tiên từ SEDA.  Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng mua gia súc còn nhỏ để nuôi & bán sau này.  Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 7.840.000 VND.  Khoản vay hiện tại sẽ được sử dụng để mua thức ăn gia súc & các loại cung cấp khác.  Khoản vay sẽ là 2nd khoản vay của người vay từ SEDA.  T. dự định sẽ sử dụng nguồn thu nhập bổ sung từ công việc kinh doanh  cải T./ mở rộng công việc kinh doanh của người vay.


Về SEDA:

Nhiệm vụ của SEDA (Trung Tâm hỗ Trợ Phát Triển các Doanh Nghiệp Nhỏ) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính vi mô cho những người có thu nhập thấp và kém may mắn trong các vùng nông thôn tại Hà Nội và các tỉnh phía Bắc Việt Nam

*Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. .  Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng  Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.  .

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed & other supplies

loans.name: Wanilia

texts.en:
Wanilia C., from the village of Banga, Wao, Lanao del Sur, is 36 years old, married, and has six school-aged children. To make a living, Wanilia owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop selling a variety of products in the local community. Engaged in her business for over three years, she earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Wanilia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Now requesting her first loan of 5,000 PHP, to be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital, she plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support her children's education.

About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and use as working capital

loans.name: Guillermo Antonio

texts.es: El señor Guillermo Antonio tiene 41 años, es casado y tiene dos hijos uno  mayor de edad y uno menor. El señor se dedica a la comercialización de zapatos, cabe señalarse el viaja a Managua a comprar y luego viaja a vender con su margen de ganancia. El señor ya tiene 5 años de tener este negocio, este negocio lo inicio cuando no encontraba trabajo como albañil, que es la otra actividad a la que él se dedica. Esta solicitando este préstamo con el objetivo de comprar mas y aprovechar la fiesta del 30 de mayo que se acerca, El aprovecha a vender en esta fecha ya sea a crédito o contado y después recupera todo el capital. Su sueño siempre ha sido llegar a establecer su tienda de zapatos en el mercado.
texts.en:
Mr. Guillermo Antonio, 41, is married and has two children, one of whom is a minor. He works selling shoes. He travels to Managua to buy his merchandise and travels back home to sell them with a markup to make a profit. He has five years working in this business, which he started when he was unable to find work as a mason. He applied for this loan with the goal of buying more merchandise and to take advantage of the May 30th holiday. He takes advantage of selling on this holiday, selling shoes on credit or paid in advance. His dream has always been to open his own shoe shop in the market.

Translated from Spanish by Patrick King, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Business capital (purchase of shoes)

loans.name: Datevi Delali

texts.en:
Datevi K. is 25 years old and has a garage where he fixes cars and sells used car parts. His garage is called "Garage Trinité." He is a mechanic who buys crashed and broken-down cars and extracts their salvageable parts to fix other people's cars. Datevi has had this garage since 2006. 

He is requesting a loan of 300,000 Communauté Financière Africaine Francs to purchase more car parts to use and resell.

loans.use: To purchase auto parts

loans.name: Melona

texts.en:
